In my opinion, no, but I will be eating here often for the convenient location, patio setting and tasty food, but probably skip out on the drinks next time. Excited for the future of this venue and hope it stays for a long time!

Fast Casual Sodikoff. So Mr. Sodikoff has replaced my beloved Roxie's with this burger "popup". Can't blame him, he'll have double, even triple the business now.  He has completely chipotle'd his famous burger into counter service with to-go capabilities and a big patio in the back. Sounds good in my book. It's nearby so I drive past it daily - over the weekend there was a line every time I went by. With one counter, it'll be difficult to speed through the line so there is a possibility of a Hot Doug's-style line in the future.  Luckily when I went there was no line and I even got to order multiple times. I may just keep going to Au Cheval and try other menu items I've always wanted to try but was afraid of burger FOMO. Hopefully the wait will be shortened now. They partnered with Kensington's to provide delicious condiments. The garlic aioli that normally accompanies the fries is now readily available in this section. Speaking of the fries, they are not the same. They're thinner and crispier, as long as you eat them quickly.   The burger you ask? It's Au Cheval-worthy. Bacon is a little thinner, but really, no complaints here. It's great as usual. Staff is very friendly and working as quick as they can. Honestly I can't believe Roxie's will ever come back. Just grab up another property and reopen it there!

The cheeseburger was amazing. Comes standard with two thin patties, two pieces of cheese, pickles, chopped onions and aioli on a delicious bun. The added bacon was also delicious and cooked to perfection. The staff were all very friendly. Once finally inside I was hand delivered a beer while waiting in line. Nice touch. Also a very cool place inside and out. Three stars because when you only serve two types of food, burgers and fries, they both better be amazing. Unfortunately the fries were not. They were extremely soggy which was a huge let down after such a long wait. Speaking of the wait, it seems like they could create some efficiency with the ordering process as the line moved extremely slow. I was there for a Hot Doug's(RIP) amount of time with a line 1/3 of the length. it was opening weekend, so I'm sure they're still working out the kinks. Hopefully I can update the review after the two glaring issues are improved upon.

I went back again and must say they've worked out the kinks.  The burger is phenomenal, put me in the minority that think it's better than Au Cheval's burger.  It's not quite as large and a bit less decadent but still plenty flavorful and big.  Most of the time that's more in line with what i'm looking for.  It's a great addition to the neighborhood on a strip of Milwaukee begging for more options.  Night and day improvement over Roxie's, much more need for a burger place than pizza by the slice in Wicker Park.

Came to Small Cheval on Sunday. The wait isn't too bad. Probably waited 25-30 minutes. The outdoor space is nice but it was very hot so we sat inside. Now, to the food. The fries are surprisingly good. Get the garlic aioli! The burger was very good. The bacon was not as thick as you'd at actual Au Cheval but the burger is good nonetheless. Glad this place opened!

Food 5 stars, service 5 stars, but giving 4 start review only because I showed up tonight at 520pm when they were supposed to be open but they were closed till 6pm. This was because they were so busy earlier in the day they needed to regroup. I would have enjoyed at least having a beer outside while we waited for opening but has to settle with starting a line in front. We all thought the burger was great. You have to get the burger as is and they are currently not accepting modifications because they are so busy. That's fine as the one they serve is delicious. There is also a single patty kids burger that's plain. They use Sir Kensington condiments which are good. The garlic aioli is also really tasty and I dipped some fries in it. I ate outside and they had napkins and water out there but thought they should have condiments outside because they were difficult to get to with the line that backed up in the inside. Fries were really good. Portion is a nice size and if you are hungry you can order one per person otherwise you could share. Beer selection on tap is pretty good and average $6-7 beer. Overall I really enjoyed the food and ambiance. I am not sure how often I would go as the line was so long to order but there is a line for good reason. I recommend you go. I'm happy I did. Good neighborhood spot.

Didn't even realize it was the opening day! Boom.  Well if you haven't been to the actual Au Cheval, you gotta go there. This is not that really. Smaller burger. Small place. Counter service. Quick sure, good sure, just not the same. Nice there isn't a wait consisting of 73619 hours though! But that might change? Who knows.  Expensive for what it is surely. $16 for burger with bacon and fries. And I tipped $2. Because you should people. They messed up the order number with me and my friend. Not a big deal and first day. And one of the dudes here offered the burger on the house. Wasn't necessary. But nice. The star off is simply for price. But we are in Chicago and Wicker Park/Bucktown so somewhat expected.  And to the dude who wrote the first review about not having vegetarian options: YOU ARE A CLOWN. Please get off Yelp. Okay thanks.

Au Cheval's younger hipster sibling has opened appropriately in Bucktown/Wicker Park. We came a little before 6pm on Friday and there were a handful of people ahead of us in line. The layout and ordering is the same as Roxie's - order at the counter and wait for your number to be called. Took about 10 minutes for us to get our order, total we were in and out in a little over 30 minutes - beats waiting two hours at Au Cheval. The cheeseburger is mostly the same here (and a dollar cheaper?!) -- similar if not same bun, similar if not same Sysco patties (a "double" is still 3 patties), same Kraft cheese, same pickles, same aioli, and same chopped onions. The bigger differences are in the additions: 1) you can order tomato and lettuce 2) no fried eggs here and 3) probably the most glaring difference is that the bacon is different. I know those who swear it's the bacon that makes the burger at Au Cheval. That peppery, maple glazed thick piece of pork belly. The bacon at Small Cheval is smaller, thinner, less maple-y, and not peppery at all. It's pretty much thicker cut bacon that you'd get on a typical burger with bacon. Sadsies. The fries are supposed to be the same as well, but they were kind sogsville when I got them. They still tasted great, just not as crispy as I remember. Hopefully it's just those first-day jitters and it'll get better. Another difference is they have milkshakes - chocolate and vanilla. I ordered chocolate but they gave me vanilla and I was too lazy to get back into the ever-growing line. The vanilla shake is made with real vanilla beans as shown by the black flecks swimming through my shake. While great in flavor, the shake itself turned soupy really quickly -- not the texture I'm looking for in a shake. Shakes need to be in that limbo between frozen popsicle and melted ice cream. Again, hoping this will get better. Milkshakes are new-ish territory for Sodikoff around here, no? The bonus on Fridays and Saturdays is that the Doughnut Vault truck parks itself outside. As if you haven't consumed enough calories, the truck tempts you with the thought of doughnuts on your way out. Also, outdoor patio has lots of seating. The Adirondack chairs are not ideal for consuming burgers, but rather for the after-effects of needing to lay back and enjoying your beer, or undoing that top button of your pants. All-in-all, I'm still ecstatic that I can walk down the street and get some version of the Au Cheval burger. I heard this might just be a temporary summer thing and Roxie's is supposed to be back in the winter. Sorry Roxie's, I think I'd prefer Small Cheval to stay forever. EDIT: Small Cheval is here to stay, yay!

Not bad. Food was good, but not great like the main location. Prices are a little high for a small burger shop- $10, but they're fancy looking, so I get it. Fries were 3 bucks. They called my number for the wrong order, so I had to switch. Luckily, it was with another member of my party, so it was no big deal (they did offer to remake it, which was nice, but not needed). Maybe just working out the opening day kinks, but the original still takes the cake.

The double patty burger comes with diced onions, a few pickles, and a messy amount of garlic aioli. It does not come with lettuce or tomato. The fries were small and better at your local fast food joint. The vanilla milkshake was delicious.  The burger was ordered with lettuce and tomato but when I got home there wasn't any. Failed. Expensive and not worth it.

Overall our first experience at Small Cheval was pretty darn great. No wait and the food was still delicious(it seems more of a fast food place). The staff was pretty awesome too. We first tried to get a seat at Au Cheval at around 4:30 (kitchen was still closed up to 5:00pm) and we were told that the wait was going to be around an hour to an hour and forty five minutes. So we gave this place a shot and seating was plentiful. No wait, great food, awesome atmosphere. Two thumbs up! Side note: A couple things to note is the menu is MUCH MUCH smaller. Also the bacon is nowhere near as good/thick as at the original place.

Best burgers. EVER.  WHO HAS TIME TO WAIT FOR A TABLE AT AU CHEVAL?? Get there. Get nice counter service. Sit down at one of the communal tables or 4 tops and eat.  Or get it to go.  And then be on your way.  Burgers are $9.  You can add bacon for a few bucks and get that sucker with cheese for another dollar.  But what you really shouldn't miss is the condiment station.  Their house-made ketchup is boss and that garlic aoili - OH MY GOD.  I would bathe in it. And boy oh boy are those burgers amazing.  Same Au Cheval burger we all know and crave minus the whole waiting for hours for a table.
